body_html:
The shared name hack will continue to work.
…
On Dec 11, 2017 01:16, "MtDersvan" ***@***.***> wrote: @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> I couldn't find the feature_column with eager support code you referred to. Can you send a link? Is a shared_name hack +/- stable? It's just such a pure joy to debug big NLP models with eager, so I'd like to make at least a somewhat proper support. btw, are there any available public roadmap for eager compatibility? — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#15212 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAATxZwPhfbZ5O54ixEPP6JiLrkVXarRks5s_IJYgaJpZM4Q7FAz> .
body_text:
The shared name hack will continue to work.
…
On Dec 11, 2017 01:16, "MtDersvan" ***@***.***> wrote:
 @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> I couldn't find the feature_column
 with eager support code you referred to. Can you send a link?
 Is a shared_name hack +/- stable?
 It's just such a pure joy to debug big NLP models with eager, so I'd like
 to make at least a somewhat proper support.
 btw, are there any available public roadmap for eager compatibility?

body:
The shared name hack will continue to work.

On Dec 11, 2017 01:16, "MtDersvan" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> I couldn't find the feature_column
> with eager support code you referred to. Can you send a link?
> Is a shared_name hack +/- stable?
> It's just such a pure joy to debug big NLP models with eager, so I'd like
> to make at least a somewhat proper support.
> btw, are there any available public roadmap for eager compatibility?
>
> —
